normalised: The year was two thousand and eighteen. Fresh out of law school, armed with my degree and a healthy dose of idealism, I landed a job at a small firm in Delhi specializing in, of all things, tax law. Tax law! I imagined myself arguing landmark cases, fighting for justice, maybe even taking on a few pro bono cases. Instead, I was wading through a sea of G-S-T returns and T-D-S deductions. Little did I know, my initiation into the world of Indian tax law would be anything but boring.

normalised: One of my first assignments involved assisting a Senior Advocate with a case related to Section eighty C of the Income Tax Act, involving a client named Mister Sharma. Mister Sharma, a sweet shop owner from Chandni Chowk, was being audited for claiming excessive deductions under eighty C. He'd declared investments in various schemes, totaling rupee two point five lakh, far exceeding the then-limit of rupee one point five lakh. The Income Tax Officer, assessing officer Mister Verma, was having none of it.

unnormalised: One of my first assignments involved assisting a Sr. Advocate with a case related to Section 80C of the Income Tax Act, involving a client named Mr. Sharma. Mr. Sharma, a sweet shop owner from Chandni Chowk, was being audited for claiming excessive deductions under 80C. He'd declared investments in various schemes, totaling ₹2.5 lakh, far exceeding the then-limit of ₹1.5 lakh. The Income Tax Officer, assessing officer Mr. Verma, was having none of it.
normalised: The challenge wasn't just the complicated calculations or the labyrinthine sections of the Act; it was dealing with Mister Sharma himself. He’d show up to meetings late, invariably with a box of jalebis (which, admittedly, was a welcome distraction). But he struggled to provide the necessary documentation. "Sir, wo sab file mein hoga," he'd say, waving his hand vaguely. "Accountant ne sambhala hoga." Finding those documents felt like an archaeological dig.

normalised: The crux of the matter was a life insurance policy purchased for his son. Mister Sharma insisted he was entitled to the deduction, but the policy was taken out in January two thousand seventeen, before his son turned eighteen. The law was clear: deductions were only permitted if the policyholder was a major. Advocate Khanna, the Senior Advocate, explained this patiently.

normalised: We spent days poring over the case files, digging up old circulars, and preparing our arguments. The hearing date was set for fifteenth March two thousand nineteen at Income Tax Bhawan. I still remember the nervous energy in the room, the rustling of papers, and the stern gaze of Mister Verma.

normalised: During the hearing, Advocate Khanna masterfully presented our case, highlighting mitigating circumstances and emphasizing Mister Sharma's genuine attempt to comply with the law. He even cited a previous judgment from the Bombay High Court as precedent. It was a tense hour, but we had presented our arguments.

normalised: In the end, the assessing officer, Mister Verma, partially accepted our arguments. While the deduction for the life insurance policy was disallowed, other deductions were approved, reducing Mister Sharma's tax liability significantly. Mister Sharma, overcome with relief, offered everyone jalebis – this time, in celebration. It was a small victory, perhaps, but it taught me a valuable lesson: that even in the seemingly dry world of tax law, there was room for empathy, understanding, and a whole lot of jalebis.
